title: Historic Manhattan Townhouse Hitting Market for $12.5M
text:
A five-story brownstone in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village that was built in 1854 for George Brodhead, who served as the president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1874-75, is coming onto the market for $12.5 million, Mansion Global has learned.



The current owner, Elizabeth Kahn-Ingleby, an expert in antiques and works of art, and her late husband, S. Sidney Kahn, a venture capitalist and art collector, bought the property in 1994 for an undisclosed amount. Mansion Global could not verify the price paid for the home.



Ms. Kahn-Ingleby said they knew this was the house for them the moment they saw it.

“Its architectural integrity and historic value were completely intact, as the house has always been a single-family and never been split up into apartments,” she wrote in an email.



While the townhouse’s scale and details were breathtaking, it needed lots of care. So the couple spent years restoring and renovating the house, Ms. Kahn-Ingleby said. The townhouse now offers every modern convenience, while respecting the integrity of the original design and architecture.



The home on West 9th Street has four bedrooms and four-and-a-half bathrooms with a total living space of 4,400 square feet. It features soaring ceilings, a sweeping staircase, and wood-burning fireplaces with marble mantles.



Ms. Kahn-Ingleby’s favorite space is the parlor level, where there is a library to the south, a gallery in the center and the living room to the north. They are all open to one another and the light flows through the rooms, she said.



They are selling the townhouse because their children are grown, and one is getting married this week in Scotland, Ms. Kahn-Ingleby said.



The townhouse of this quality inside out is extremely rare, said Leslie Mason of Douglas Elliman, who is listing the property on Wednesday.



“Having sold houses in the village for over 20 years and having lived in the neighborhood almost all my life, I cannot remember ever seeing a house this graceful and complete,” she said. “Everywhere you sit or stand, there is beauty.”

The townhouse market is in some ways independent from the rest of the real estate market in New York, Ms. Mason said. “Sometimes a townhouse sale is immediate and sometimes it takes years.”



Most townhouse buyers are looking for something longer-lasting, and have a vision for their futures, she said. Often they are beginning their families, or making a new transition in their lives. “They want independence and privacy to live as they wish.”

The median price of a Manhattan townhouse increased 53% from $3.1 million to $5.2 million in the decade from 2009 to 2018. The price appreciation is twice as fast as that of Manhattan apartments, according to a Douglas Elliman report published in January.
